unnormalised: Okay, so my uncle just asked me, "Beta, what is this 'www' everyone is talking about? Is it some new chai stall website?" Lol! I nearly choked on my samosa! He's usually pretty tech-savvy, always forwarding good morning images on WhatsApp and knows how to use Google. Turns out, he's never really understood what all those letters at the beginning of a URL actually mean. He just kinda accepts them, like the "Dr." before Dr. Sharma's name.
normalised: Okay, so my uncle just asked me, "Beta, what is this triple W everyone is talking about? Is it some new chai stall website?" Laughing out loud! I nearly choked on my samosa! He's usually pretty tech-savvy, always forwarding good morning images on WhatsApp and knows how to use Google. Turns out, he's never really understood what all those letters at the beginning of a U-R-L actually mean. He just kinda accepts them, like the "Dr." before Doctor Sharma's name.

unnormalised: Seriously though, explaining "World Wide Web" to someone who thinks the internet is just Facebook and YouTube is a challenge! I tried to break it down - it's basically a giant spider web, but instead of catching insects, it catches cat videos and fake news. Each website is a "node," and the "http://" or "https://" (which, by the way, he now thinks is "hyper tea transfer protocol") is how the web browser knows how to talk to that website. I even threw in "TCP/IP" just to mess with him, and he gave me the most bewildered look!
normalised: Seriously though, explaining "World Wide Web" to someone who thinks the internet is just Facebook and YouTube is a challenge! Each website is a "node," and the "H-T-T-P colon slash slash" or "H-T-T-P-S colon slash slash" (which, by the way, he now thinks is "hyper tea transfer protocol") is how the web browser knows how to talk to that website. I even threw in "T-C-P slash I-P" just to mess with him, and he gave me the most bewildered look!

unnormalised: Anyway, after a 20-minute explanation involving drawings on a napkin and comparing it to the railway network (each website is a station, and the URL is the train route!), I think he *sort of* got it. He still thinks "URL" sounds like some kind of South Indian dish, but at least he now knows "www" isn't a secret code for ordering extra sugar in his chai. Maybe I'll explain "bandwidth" next Diwali... wish me luck!
